concern: Iâ€™m feeling nervous about college and debating if iâ€™ve picked the right one. Iâ€™m already registered for classes and I have my dorm room/roomate all set but I canâ€™t help but feel nervous. Does/Did anyone feel this way? Iâ€™m very introverted and I feel like I wonâ€™t be able to make friends because Iâ€™m just awkward.

dialogue_total.statement: Hello there! I'm so glad you're here today. Feel free to share anything on your mind, whether it's a concern, a thought, or even just something you'd like to chat about. I'm here to listen and support you in any way I can. ðŸ˜Š

Hey, thanks for being here to talk. Iâ€™ve just been feeling really nervous about starting college and whether I made the right choice, and Iâ€™m kinda worried about fitting in since Iâ€™m pretty introverted.

That sounds really stressful, especially when you're already feeling uncertain about your decision. It's understandable that you're worried about fitting in, but remember that being introverted doesn't mean you won't make friends. It just means you might need to find people who appreciate your quieter nature.
Thanks, that makes me feel a bit better to hear. I just keep overthinking everything, ya know, like whether Iâ€™ll even click with anyone or if Iâ€™ll just end up feeling out of place all the time.

That's a lot to process all at once, and it's natural to feel anxious about the unknown. But remember, you don't have to have everything figured out right away. Let's talk about what you're hoping to get out of college and what your ideal social circle would look like.

Yeah, I guess Iâ€™m just hoping college will be a place where I can grow and figure out who I am, ya know? Iâ€™d love to have a small group of close friends who get me, but Iâ€™m not even sure how to start finding them.

It sounds like you have a good idea of what you're hoping to get out of college, both academically and socially. You mentioned wanting a small group of close friends who understand you, which is a great goal. Have you thought about any specific ways you might start finding those people, like joining clubs or organizations that align with your interests?

Yeah, Iâ€™ve thought about maybe joining a club or something, but I get kinda anxious just thinking about putting myself out there. Iâ€™m not sure Iâ€™d even know how to start a convo or if Iâ€™d feel weird being in a new group.

It's great that you're thinking about joining a club or organization. While it's natural to feel anxious about starting conversations in a new group, remember that everyone there is likely feeling the same way. What if you start by observing and listening for a bit, and then look for opportunities to contribute to the conversation when you feel comfortable? And if you're feeling overwhelmed, it's always okay to take a break and step outside for a moment to collect your thoughts.
Yeah, I like the idea of just observing at first, that feels less intimidating. I guess Iâ€™m just worried Iâ€™ll still feel out of place or like I donâ€™t belong even after trying, ya know?

It's totally understandable to feel like you might not fit in right away, but remember that building connections takes time and effort. It's okay to start small and focus on one or two people you feel comfortable with. What are some things you think would make you feel more at ease in a new group?

Hmm, I think maybe if I could find people who share some of my interests, like books or movies, thatâ€™d help me feel more at ease. I just donâ€™t know how to spot those people or bring it up without feeling super awkward about it.

That's a great point, sharing common interests can be a great way to connect with others. One idea could be to look for clubs or groups that focus on books or movies, like a book club or a film appreciation group. You could also try asking people about their interests in a casual way, like mentioning a book or movie you've enjoyed and seeing if anyone else has an opinion on it. It's all about taking small steps and finding opportunities to engage with others in a way that feels comfortable for you.

Yeah, that makes sense, starting with a club thatâ€™s already about something I like could take some of the pressure off. Iâ€™m just kinda nervous about even walking into one of those meetings and figuring out how to jump into a convo without feeling like Iâ€™m forcing it.

It's completely normal to feel that way, especially when stepping into an unfamiliar environment. You could try arriving a few minutes early to the meeting, so you have some time to observe the group dynamic before fully joining in. Remember, you don't have to jump into a conversation right away. Take your time, listen, and when you feel ready, you could try asking someone a question about the book or movie being discussed, or share a thought you have.
Thanks, thatâ€™s a good tip about getting there early to kinda scope things out. I just hope I donâ€™t freeze up when itâ€™s time to actually say something, ya know?

That's completely understandable, and it's great that you're thinking ahead. You could try practicing what you might say beforehand, or even writing down some conversation starters to help you feel more prepared. Remember, it's okay to take your time and speak when you feel comfortable.

Yeah, I like the idea of practicing a bit before I go, maybe just running through a couple things I could mention about a book or movie. Itâ€™s just tough â€˜cause I overthink stuff and end up worrying Iâ€™ll sound dumb or out of place, ya know?

I understand how daunting it can feel to step out of your comfort zone, especially when you're worried about sounding awkward or out of place. But remember, everyone else in that room is probably feeling a little nervous too, and they're all there for the same reason: to connect over a shared interest. By preparing a few conversation starters and taking your time to observe the group dynamic, you'll be giving yourself the best chance to ease into the situation without feeling overwhelmed.

Thanks for reminding me that Iâ€™m not the only one who might be nervousâ€”it helps to think of it that way. Iâ€™ll definitely try to keep those tips in mind and not put too much pressure on myself. So, um, do you think itâ€™s worth checking out a couple different clubs to see which one feels like the best fit, or should I just stick to one for now?

Great question! It's a good idea to explore a few clubs to see which ones resonate with you and your interests. That way, you can get a sense of the different group dynamics and find a community where you feel comfortable and supported. Remember, it's okay to take your time and try out a few different options before committing to one. And don't forget to keep those conversation starters handy and practice them beforehand to help ease any nerves you might feel. You've got this!

Thanks, I appreciate the encouragement to check out a few options without rushing to decide. So, uh, I guess Iâ€™ll start by looking up some meeting times this week and see whatâ€™s out thereâ€”do you think just showing up to watch at first is okay, or should I try to jump in right away?
